rawLines.text: But when you were writing The Kill
Chain, I mean, it is true that you saw
where the future of warfare was headed
unlike anyone else. And I would love for
you to talk about, you know, what did
you get right? Where were your
predictions right? And and where has you
have you seen sort of uh the future play
out? And then maybe what surprised you,
maybe maybe what changed that you
weren't expecting. Yeah. um when when I
was writing the book and when I was
doing like what little research I
actually did for it because I was
working full-time at Andreal which was
very much a full-time job and uh writing
the book was something I did between the
hours of like 3:00 in the morning and 8
in the morning in California when I was
on East Coast time sitting in my hotel
room. Um I think the thing that was
striking to me was how much of what I
was saying had been said for like 25
years. Um and and the real story was how
little of what we had been saying
collectively we needed to do was
actually being done. Um so I think in
that respect you know in terms of the
things that I got right I'm not going to
sit here and suggest that like you know
I discovered a new law of you know
kinematics like I think that uh a lot of
it had been ground that had been trod
before. Um I think what's changed is how
quickly that change has actually played
out and far faster than I would have
thought. Um, I mean, when I was writing
it, you know, I kind of believed that
these types of changes that I was
writing about that many people in this
room are are working uh to push forward
every day could happen incredibly
quickly, right, if we got out of our own
way, if the government were better. Um
but to see how fast it's actually
playing out, right? To sit here 5 years
later and you know look at uh a room
full of founders who are working in
defense technology, multiple companies
valued over a billion dollars performing
on capabilities and programs for the
Department of Defense that you know
people whose first name is secretary and
chief are concentrated on. I thought,
you know, maybe we'd get there by the
latter part of the decade, which, you
know, I was worried it was going to take
too long, but the fact that we're now at
this place and, you know, the beginning
of 2025 is kind of amazing. Yeah. What
what what is how has it affected how,
you know, Android chooses to make
products because I think, you know, in
in the beginning when you joined it was
you were working on one product, but you
were working on Lattis. I mean, a lot of
the kind of scaffolding of the original
vision is still there, but now you were
doing so much um to keep up with the
demand, to keep up with the fact that
you called the future, right? How has it
changed sort of the how the organization
has has has grown? Yeah, I I think it's
um it's sort of shocking when I think
back to the six and a half years ago
when I started at Anderoll. Much of what
we said we wanted to do are things that
we're now doing. Um we just never would
have believed that we would be capable
of doing them on the timeline that we're
now doing them on. Um but the sort of
movement into all domain uh autonomous
systems uh the movement into real
weapons production um all of it
obviously kind of software defined all
of it sort of defined by commercial
technology um that was kind of the game
plan from the get-go and you know I
think a lot of the specificity has been
very much something that the government
has driven with different programs and
requirements um but from the beginning
that was that was the original vision
right and and the smaller things that we
were working on you know the stuff that
fits in the lobby out here. They were
great programs. You know, many of them
are still phenomenal programs that are
making a difference for war fighters.
They're important to the business. But I
think we always had a sort of more
ambitious guys of this is where we're
going to start, but it's going to help
us level up to larger systems, things
that are longer range, carry more
payload, more relevant to an Admiral
Paparro, uh, you know, out in Indoacific
Command. Totally. Well, and it's
interesting you mentioned Indoacific
because so much changed too with
Ukraine, but then of course you're
you're working for multiple theaters.
you now have a space business. I mean,
there there's so much that you're doing
now um that's not just directly related
to kind of now. It's it's really related
to the future. So, maybe talk a little
bit about that, how you plan for those
products, whether it's things that are
happening in Ukraine or or things that
are happening in India Pacific. Yeah.
And I'm I'm glad you mentioned Ukraine
because I think that's actually been the
biggest catalyst, right? I mean, I think
many of the things that I was writing
about in the book, many things that
others were talking about and writing
about at the same time, they were all
kind of interesting. they had sort of a,
you know, a science fiction cast or, you
know, kind of an interesting think tank
cast. Um, then to see it all kind of
play out in high relief in Ukraine and,
you know, the the the the lines of it
had been there for folks who had been
paying attention. But I think that was
the sort of collective realization that
a lot of people had that, oh wow, all of
these kind of lowcost more autonomous
things can kill tanks, they can kill
battleships. Um, you know, this is a war
of mass and attrition and production.
These are not going to be short wares,
they're going to be long wars. um you
know the the sort of meat and potatoes
of what great power competition actually
is if we look back historically that I
think has just kind of completely opened
up the conversation and and really kind
of created a lot of the energy that
we're now seeing. So for us at Andreal I
mean it's really been uh a similar type
of focus on hey we're obviously going to
sit down and we're going to work closely
with the government. We're going to
listen to what the government uh has to
say. um you know to borrow a line from
Palmer he said you know I will always be
interested in the government's
definition of its problems um but I'm
not going to necessarily believe that
they know what the right solution to
that problem is. Amen. Um so the
willingness to you know sit down in the
room and actually kind of ideate um to
to tell people when we think that
they're wrong and kind of push in a
different direction and then obviously
having the courage of our own
convictions to put IRA behind the things
that we're looking to build. I mean
that's how a space business got started
for us, right? I mean, it wasn't like we
just magicked into uh a gigantic space
program. I mean, it was years of
investment and work that sort of earned
us the right to not get laughed out of
the room when we showed up and said,
"Look, I think we have something to
offer here." Totally. I mean, the other
thing that's really changed that that I
think is really extraordinary that we
couldn't have couldn't have expected
post Ukraine is you were in many ways
alone. You were the, you know, the first

companies for obvious reasons that have
been talked about. Defense was taboo in

build uh you know in that pre2022 era.
Now you have this array you can see it
out in the lobby this array of companies
that are operating that want to partner
many are are subbing to each other many
are working on programs together did you
predict that that would happen and how
has it changed how Android thinks about
its business now that there's so many
other companies that can potentially be
either a supplier or a partner. Yeah, I
I mean it's a it's awesome, right? I
mean I think in the in the early days uh
you know there were obviously other
companies that had had sort of like
plowed a lot of that ground for us when
when uh Andreal got started, right? I
mean uh certainly Shield but before that
even Palanteer, SpaceX, others um there

I mean just the explosion of interest
and energy uh you know frankly just kind
of the strength and numbers right I mean
when you're kind of off doing it on your
own you kind of in those times of
reflection say like maybe I'm crazy and
this whole thing is uh the wrong
pursuit. Um you know to just see uh how
much interest there is in this how much
energy is just super exciting. Um and
it's helpful, right? I think uh the
conversation in Washington has changed
completely uh around uh the types of
companies that can do this work and
frankly now the expectation that we need
them to do this work. Um you know back
when we got started I mean it was sort
of a you know you have to kind of
explain your reason for being and
justify your existence when you would go
into these meetings. And you know, my
sense is uh there's now a lot more kind
of wind at the sort of collective back
of people in this room where it's less
about having to convince people that you
can do it. Uh and it's more walking into
rooms where people are expecting that
you are the kind of company or you're
the type of capability uh that is going
to answer the biggest problems that they
have. So just that sort of uh again
strength and numbers the ecosystem and
then for us as a company the ability to
have teammates across the sort of
defense technology uh ecosystem is
fantastic. I mean I just got back from
uh project convergence capstone with uh
the army out at Fort Irwin uh where we
were teamed up on a command and control
program uh with a lot of different
companies uh many of whom are in this
room many more to come. uh the ability
to sort of pull companies that have the
same kind of DNA that want to go quickly
that are uh risk tolerant that are going
to lean in. I mean those are the best
kind of partners to have um whether you
know we're subbing to them or they're
subbing to us or it's not even that kind
of a relationship. Um just having that
kind of talent on the field is better
for everybody. Totally. Well, similar to
to SpaceX, I think this year, especially
2025, I haven't there really hasn't been
a day where you haven't broken news
about a new program, a new product. I
mean it really is just incredible the
pace at which Anderrell is working. I
would love to understand you know you're
you're not a startup anymore. U you know
I think sometimes people say you're you
know you're now eight years old but
you're you're actually a company that
has grown to to such size. What are the
next 5 10 years look like for Andre?
Yeah. Um we we kind of go round and
round on this right. It's like we're
we're not a startup but we're not big by
defense standards. Like we're not a
prime but we're larger. I mean we
haven't figured out yet what to call
ourselves.
Um the next five years I think look like
a couple of things. I mean one is
production at scale, right? So we've had
to kind of like fight our way out of
Earth's atmosphere on a lot of programs
uh where we're now in a position on
large contracts where we have to deliver
systems at scale. Um and that journey
has been something that we've been on
now for the past few years. Um really
digging deep into how manufacturing and
defense can be done totally differently
to get different types of outcomes. So
whether it's low-cost cruise missiles,
collaborative combat aircraft, you know,
large and extra-large autonomous
undersea vehicles or a host of other
things, um the real challenge for us
over the next 5 years is proving that we
can deliver these systems uh on time, on
cost, uh you know, that we can scale to
the quantities that we believe are going
to be necessary and that the government
partners we're working with uh
increasingly are wanting. So we've got
to prove all that out. Um then at the
same time, I think it's it's a whole
bunch of new territory that we're
excited to move into, right? I mean, you
know, whether it's Soldierorn Mission
Command following the, uh, you know,
kind of the acquisition of the IVAS
program, uh, the ability to just
revolutionize what it means to be a
soldier on the battlefield, you know,
connected to systems and sensors that
extend your, uh, you know, kind of
agency and awareness beyond line of
sight, beyond the reach of your own
arms. Um, I mean, that's an incredibly
exciting frontier. I mean, that's if
anything, uh, Palmer Lucky was put on
Earth to do, it is revolutionizing that.
So, that's going to be wildly exciting.
And then I think just getting to larger
scale, right? So this journey that we've
been on has been starting with systems
that we thought were big and then
realizing that actually there's a much
larger version uh kind of around the
corner uh that's going to be relevant
for the war fighter because it's longer
range, it carries more payload, it's a
more capable system. Um and by the way,
it still can be mass manufactured. It
can be built and bought at low cost. Um
and it can deployed in large numbers. So
I I think whether it's, you know, space
systems, undersea systems, uh aircraft
or other things, there's just a lot of
new products and programs out there that
we're excited to uh to to create and
build. Totally. I want to ask you too
about the broader defense tech movement
because it's hot right now. Investors
are super excited about investing in
defense technology. Founders are super
excited for building for it, but we
don't take that as a given, right? Like
that it will always be there. So I would
love to understand what your message is
for the DoD on how to take advantage of
this unique moment where there's this
incredible investment subsidy for R&D
where there's this incredible movement
of founders wanting to build for their
country. What's your advice to them to
take advantage of it? Yeah, the um a lot
of the advice is you've got to kind of
play the long game here. um you know and
I think we've had our trials and
tribulations and false starts and
missteps as a company and you know at
each step of the way you know we've been
fortunate to have government partners
have understood that that's kind of a
feature not a bug um and I think that's
broadly true for the defense technology
ecosystem uh of companies as a whole um
you know the companies that are here
today might not necessarily be all the
companies that are here in 5 to 10 years
um you know we're all going to make
missteps we're all going to you know
step on rakes and and do bad things, you
know, we're going to run quickly and
field prototypes that don't work. But I
think that's the point that the
government is starting to understand,
which is that is the way you actually
get good technology. Uh, and the
alternative is worse, right? The
alternative of give me $100 billion in
10 years and leave me alone and then
like you'll have this amazing whisbang
thing. Um, most of the time that stuff
never shows up. So this more iterative,
fast-moving, you know, highly kind of
fluid, slightly chaotic approach, uh, is
something that I think people in
government are increasingly comfortable
with. Um, frankly, many of them are
excited by it. I mean, um, you know, the
other thing that I think should not go,
uh, you know, unsaid is how many people
in government have kind of been waiting
for this, right? I mean, they're they're
similar ages to many of us in this room.
They've lived their whole lives with
broken and bad technology. they use
technology in their day-to-day lives
that like kick the ass of the things
that they're handed to, you know, in in
government service. Um, and they just
know that there's something better out
there. And the fact that you now have
this kind of group of companies showing
up and actually delivering on the very
thing that these people have secretly
wanted their whole lives and now uh, you
know, are are able to get. Um, there's
an enormous excitement that I detect in
government for that and for people like
this in this room. Um, and it's an
awesome thing to be a part of. Totally.

Uh it's a great question.
Um, I think
the the things that I would probably
spend more time on in the book, uh, are
really the things that that frankly I've
been spending a lot of time on in recent
years, which is all around production
and manufacturing. Um, it was kind of in
there, but it just wasn't a point of

look back historically,
um, the past 25, 30 years is just a

America being top of the heap, laps
ahead of the competition. you know, the
idea of a great power peer threat just
wasn't even on anybody's radar or
horizon. Um, most of human history
hasn't been that way. And if you just

a significant and robust industrial
base, the ability to produce at scale,
the ability to replenish when you lose
large numbers of things, which you

power competition or conflict. Um I I
think that has become uh really the

and advanced manufacturing and other
things softwaredefined systems
commercial technology has a significant

in traditional industry kind of break
our you know break their arms patting

if god forbid we ever end up in the type
